typical_structure.element: Journal logo (Figure or Artifact depending on placement)
Authors with affiliation superscripts (P with References)
Methods, Results, Discussion sections (Sect with H2)
References section (Sect with H2, list of citations)
Footer with copyright, DOI, page number (Artifact or P with roles)
Management sections with subsections (Sect with H2, nested Sect with H3)
Treatment algorithms (Figure with detailed alt text)
Footer information (Artifact or P with roles)

reading_order.step: Read left column from top to bottom
Then read right column from top to bottom
Exception: If content explicitly flows across columns (newspaper style), follow that flow
Footnotes at bottom should be placed after main content, not in visual position

issue.name: Skipped Heading Levels
issue.problem: Input shows H1 followed by H3 with no H2

solution.option: If the H3 is truly a subsection, insert a logical H2 or adjust levels
If the "H3" is actually decorative or a label, consider making it a P or Aside
Consult the visual context to determine true hierarchy

issue.name: Ambiguous Element Type
issue.problem: Element could be content or artifact (e.g., logo, repeated text)

solution.guideline: If it appears once and is part of document identity → Content (Figure)
If it repeats on every page in margins → Artifact
If it provides information users need → Content

issue.name: Complex Tables
issue.problem: Table structure is unclear from element extraction

solution.step: Look for patterns in element order and position
If uncertain, create basic table structure and note in comments

issue.name: Footnote Matching
issue.problem: Matching footnote markers to footnote content

solution.step: Look for superscript numbers/symbols in paragraph content
Match to footnote elements with same number/symbol
Add Reference elements at marker locations with matching RefIDs

issue.name: Missing Alt Text Information
issue.problem: Input doesn't describe images, only identifies them

solution.step: Use context clues from surrounding text
If caption is present, use it as basis for alt text
If figure is referenced in text ("Figure 1 shows..."), use that description
For charts: describe type and general content ("Bar chart comparing treatment outcomes")

practice.title: Start with Structure
practice.description: Map out the document hierarchy before creating detailed elements. Understand the big picture first.

practice.title: Think Like a Screen Reader User
practice.description: Imagine navigating the document without seeing it. Does the structure make sense? Can you skip to sections? Is the reading order logical?

practice.title: Be Consistent
practice.description: Use consistent naming for IDs (Note1, Note2, Fig1, Fig2). Use consistent structure for similar elements.

practice.title: Provide Context in Comments
practice.description: Add XML comments to explain non-obvious decisions, especially for complex structures or ambiguous elements.

practice.title: Validate Cross-References
practice.description: Double-check that every RefID points to an existing ID. Missing references break navigation.

practice.title: Don't Over-Structure
practice.description: Not every visual grouping needs a Sect. Use sections for meaningful semantic divisions, not just visual layout.

practice.title: Meaningful Alt Text
practice.description: Alt text should convey the same information as the image. For decorative images, mark as Artifact instead.

quality_indicators.good_sign: Every input element is accounted for
Reading order makes sense when read linearly
Heading hierarchy is logical and complete
Alt text is descriptive and meaningful
quality_indicators.warning_sign: Large number of elements marked as artifacts (may be over-marking)
Very flat structure (no sections or nesting)

example.name: Well-Structured Section
example.code:
MANAGEMENT OF ADVANCED DISEASE

Binet stage A and B with active disease or Binet stage C

The treatment algorithms for first-line (Figure 1) and relapsed therapy (Figure 2) have been updated. Figure 1 Figure 2

First-line treatment

Different treatment strategies are available...

example.name: Proper Footnote Handling
example.code:
B. Eichhorst ¹ , P. Ghia ² ³

Department I for Internal Medicine, University of Cologne, Germany Medical School, Università Vita-Salute San Raffaele, Milan

why_excellent.reason: Enables screen reader to jump from marker to note and back
